name: COL3A1 Mutations in Vascular Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
description: Vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome (vEDS) results from heterozygous mutations in the COL3A1 gene encoding type III procollagen. Over 600 different mutations have been identified, with the majority being missense mutations affecting glycine residues in the Gly-X-Y triplet repeat. Genotype-phenotype correlations exist, with certain mutation types conferring higher vascular risk. Understanding the genetics is essential for diagnosis, prognosis, and family counseling.

content.statement: aku:vascular:genetic:eds-002-col3a1 is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Genetic-Ctd that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

definitions_glossary.concept: A fundamental idea or notion in the domain
definitions_glossary.property: A characteristic or attribute of an entity
definitions_glossary.relationship: A connection or association between concepts

normal_function.structure: Triple helix formed by three alpha-1(III) chains

triple_helix.requirement: Glycine in every third position (Gly-X-Y repeat)
triple_helix.rationale: Glycine is smallest amino acid, fits in helix core

procollagen_processing: 3. Triple helix forms from C to N terminus

glycine_substitutions.mechanism: Glycine replaced by larger amino acid
glycine_substitutions.severity: Location-dependent (more C-terminal may be more severe)

splice_site_mutations.effect: Exon skipping leads to abnormal protein

null_mutations.phenotype: Often milder than dominant negative mutations

potentially_milder.haploinsufficiency: Null mutations may be less severe

dominant_negative_effect.mechanism: Mutant chains incorporate into triple helix
dominant_negative_effect.result: Helix instability, secretion defects, matrix abnormalities
dominant_negative_effect.ratio: 75% of collagen molecules contain at least one mutant chain

haploinsufficiency.clinical: May be associated with milder phenotype

tissue_effects.blood_vessels: Thin, fragile arterial walls prone to rupture
tissue_effects.intestine: Weak intestinal wall, prone to perforation

molecular_genetic_testing.technique: Next-generation sequencing panels or targeted testing

biochemical_testing.findings: Abnormal type III collagen migration on gel electrophoresis
biochemical_testing.limitation: Rarely used now due to advances in genetic testing

family_screening.importance: Identify at-risk individuals before vascular events

arginine_to_cysteine_variant.special_consideration: Some arginine-to-cysteine variants may have variable expressivity
arginine_to_cysteine_variant.clinical_significance: May require careful interpretation with clinical correlation

clinical_pearls: Glycine substitutions are most common mutation type (~60%)
Dominant negative mutations often more severe than haploinsufficiency
~50% of vEDS cases are de novo - no family history doesn't exclude diagnosis
Genetic confirmation is essential for definitive diagnosis and family screening
learning_objectives: Classify COL3A1 mutation types and their effects on type III collagen
Explain genotype-phenotype correlations in vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
Describe the genetic counseling implications for vEDS families

prerequisites.title: Vascular Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome Overview
prerequisites.reason: Must understand vEDS to appreciate genetic details

related.relationship: Tissue fragility from collagen defects drives surgical approach

sources.source: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st ed. McGraw-Hill.
